creditline: Gift of Ruth and Bruce Dayton
department: Chinese, South and Southeast Asian Art
description: in the form of a shou character; curved handle and long s-form spout; slightly recessed base; diaper design in yellow, green and black between raised mauve edges; handle and spout simulate bamboo
medium: Porcelain with enamel decor painted on bisquit
text: Hand built in the form of a shou (longevity) character with a curved handle and long s-formed spout, this unusually exuberant, seemingly modern wine vessel was made over three hundred years ago. Character-form wine pots were made in three shapes: shou (longevity), fu (happiness), and lu (emolument) during the Kang-hsi reign (1662-1772). The porcelain is enameled on the bisquit with a diaper design in yellow-green and black. The handle and spout simulate wrapped bamboo.
title: Wine Ewer
